intro: Astripomoea malvacea var. floccosa, commonly known as the woolly mallow, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its soft, fuzzy leaves that give it a distinctive, velvety appearance. The plant produces showy, pale pink to lavender flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and borders. Its botanical features include a stout, branching stem and hairy calyces surrounding its five-petaled flowers.
